JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 28.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 25, 1914.

LEHIGH TRACK MEN MET DEFEAT

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

PRESIDENT GOODNOW'S FIRST MESSAGE TO HOPKINS STUDENTS

HARVARD DOWNED SECOND TIME

'Varsity Athletes Piled Up 63 Points to
Opponents' 41—One Record Broken.
Connolly Elected Captain.

Return Game at Cambridge Won By
One Point Margin--Pillow Fights and
Meeting of "Old Friends" Features.

The 'Varsity track and field team
lived up to expectations Saturday
at Homewood, downing Lehigh's
representatives 63 points to 41.
There was a stiff breeze during
the meet which prevented fast
times, and only one record fell, although two members of the Hopkins squad had hoped to establish
new marks. Randall, of Lehigh,
clipped an inch off the pole-vault
record when he went over the bar
at ii feet 8 inches.
There were several fast and hotly
contested events, and the meet was
a fitting close to Hopkins' spring
season.
The 200-yard dash was interesting because of a thrilling finish.
Lloyd had second position until the
last 20 yards, but nosed ahead on
a beautiful spurt, making the distance in 22 seconds. Lloyd was
also first in the 44o-yard run.
"Ben" Tappan, of Hopkins, won
both hurdle events; Swan, of Hopkins, being second in the 120-yard
event, and Turner Binford second
in the 220.
Harry Wagner won the woyard dash, but the time, toYs seconds, was higher than his usual
mark.
"Freddie" Lee, running his last
race for Hopkins, was first in the
two-mile. He won the event by
half a lap over Burns, of Lehigh.
After the meet, Gerald Connolly
was unanimously .selected to captain
next year's track and field team.
He is the veteran high juniper of
the squad, and will succeed Harry
Wagner, who will leave the University this year.
The summary:

For the second time this year the
lacrosse team triumphed over Harvard, the score being 5 to 4. The
team, accompanied by Messrs. W.
Schmeisser, Wolfe and H. Burgan,
left for Boston on Friday evening,
and in spite of several pillow-fights
and pajama parades, arrived safely
at their destination on Saturday
morning. After partaking of an
excellent feed at the Harvard 'Varsity' Club, the team departed for
the stadium to witness part of the
Harvard-Princeton baseball game
and the New England Intercollegiate Track Meet.
The game was called shortly after
four o'clock, and after the ball had
see-sawed up and down the field,
Hopkins scored the first tally. This
was followed a few minutes later
by one of ex-Capt. Houck's hard
shots, which resulted in a second
goal. Before the end of the half,
Abbe, though closely cornered,
managed to slip one past Goalkeeper Sears.
•
During the intermission, the team
was encopraged by the presence of
"Gil" Horax, "Jimmy" Easter, Ellis Ellicott, T. B. Price and Groundkeeper Chalk.
Hopkins, as usual, started the
second period with a rush, and in
a short time Voshell netted a pretty
goal from scrimmage. Harvard
showed good fighting qualities and
before the Hopkins defence could
recover, Nightingale and Fleming
both scored. To even up matters,
first Troxell then Voshell scored
for Hopkins. With seven minutes
to play, Elliott rolled an easy one
past Sears, who did not see it, making the score 5 to 4, in Hopkins'
favor.
In spite of strenuous efforts,
there was no more scoring by either
side. One of the features of the
game was the splendid work of
Captain Sutton, who repeatedly
captured the ball from the Harvard
attack and carried it past the midfield.

RHODES SCHOLARS DO WELL

GOOD CHEMISTS IN DEMAND

UNIVERSITY CALENDAR

Americans at Oxford Succeed in Nearly
All Activities According to Annual
Report—Not So Good in Classics.

Professor Baxter Tells of Wide Opportunities in the Industrial Field —"Efficiency Chemists" Needed.

The annual report of the Rhodes
scholarship trust, which has just
been issued, contains a statement
giving the young American Rhodes
scholars at Oxford credit for filling
well an important place in the life
and work of the ancient University. There are 175 scholarship
holders, about one-fourteenth of the
whole student body, a number that
offers abundant opportunity for influence on both sides.
The report grants that it is difficult to appraise relative merit, but
concedes that the Rhodes men are
standing the test of Oxford competition well in all studies, except the
classics. Last year they took five
out of the seven first honors in
jurisprudence. They won nine university prizes, some of them of
great importance — the Gladstone
memorial prize, the Mathew Arnold
prize for an English essay; the Oldham prize for a classical essay, and
the Beit prize in colonial history.
The 1913 prizes and honors won
by Rhodes men last year were more
numerous than in any earlier year.
An American also won last year,
for the first time, the presidency of
the Union, the highest undergraduate office. • In athletics they are
conspicuous. In the Oxford competition with Cambridge last year
five Americans were on the track
team.
Finally, the report sets at rest a
fear that some felt when the scholarships were established. Of the
431 Rhodes scholars who have finished their studies, only eleven have
gone to work in England, and most
of these only as a temporary arrangement. The remainder have
returned home, 144 to pursue education professionally, 113 law, 47
government service, 25 medicine, 18
business, 18 ministry, and others
journalism, scientific work and
farming.

Prof. G. P. Baxter, writing in the
Harvard Crimson, believes there is
a wide field of oportunity open to
efficient chemists in a great many
industries which heretofore have
not been concerned with the science.

FORMULATE NEW HAZING RULES
Freshman Committee Has Submitted to
the Faculty and Student Council
a Code of Regulations.

.\ ,vstem of hazing, based upon
a Code of Regulations which future
Hopkins freshmen will be expected
"to submit to and to obey," has
been presented to the Student
Council and the faculty by the
committee of freshmen on hazing
and freshman regulations, William
J. Fulton, chairman.
No action has been taken on the
new rules by either the Student
Council or the faculty, but if they
are accepted in whole or in part,
the first-year men will be expected
to follow them faithfully.
The greater part of the Code of
Regulations has been copied from
the system followed at Princeton,
while the rules for hazing represent, for the most part, the ideas
of the committee.
The verbatim report of the freshman committee is:
Since promiscuous hazing has
been abolished at this University,
yet believing that if it is done
systematically and in the right
spirit it will be of value to the
University and to the freshmen, we
submit to the Student Council and
the faculty of the Johns Hopkins
University a system of hazing and
a Code of Regulations which the
freshmen of this University are
expected to submit to and to obey.
Regulations.
1. Freshmen should not be boisterous, talk loudly, or- make unnecessary noises in or about the
buildings.
2. At no time during the year
should freshmen ride in the elevators.
3. Freshmen should show respect
to upper classmen by giving way
to them in all reasonable ways.
4. On or before the day of the
St. John's football game, freshmen
should not wear derby. hats or tan
shoes.
5. Until Commemoration Day,
freshmen should not wear loud
socks, vests, or ties, or shirts with
soft collars.
6. Freshmen should not wear
University colors in any form (permissible when representing the University in athletics).
7. Freshmen should not smoke
pipes or cigars on University property.
8. Freshmen should always carry
matches as a favor to upper classmen.
9. Unless accompanied by visitors or relatives no freshman should
occupy a seat in the stands at
Homewood Field, other than in the
rooters' section.
Freshmen should be present
at all athletic contests at Homewood Field.
1. Freshmen should be present
at every student meeting, at which
their presence is deemed important
by the organization holding it.

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 25, 1914.
12. The wearing of silk hats to
University functions is the privilege of juniors and seniors only.
13. Freshmen should wear the
"freshman button- always in the
lapel of the coat, in plain view.
While the University remains in
the city, the term "University property," in the seventh regulation, applies to that district bounded on the
north by Madison street, on the
south by Franklin street, on the
east by Howard street, and on the
west by Eutaw street. It also applies to all Homewood property.
As we think it unreasonable to
expect the freshmen to wear a
special skull cap in the city, we substitute, in the thirteenth regulation,
some form of button by which the
upper classmen can tell who are
freshmen. The form of this button
may be decided on by a committee.
The caps can be substituted for the
buttons when the University moves
to Homewood.

Hazing.
No secret or disorganized hazing
should be permitted to be indulged
in.
Let the third school day after the
second term begins be called Judgment Day. On this day at twothirty all freshmen are expected to
be present in the Cage. They should
be ready to do everything they
are ordered to do without complaint. A "Judgment" committee
of half the sophomore, one-third of
the junior and twenty of the senior
class be appointed by the class
presidents. This committee shall
meet a sufficient number of times
to assign tasks for each individual
freshman and to make complete arrangements for the affair. This
committee shall consider it their
duty to assign tasks to the individual
according to his conduct, freshness,.
or meekness. In this way the fresh
freshman will get his just deserts,
and the meek one who frequently
gets more than his share will be
justly treated. The Student Council should decide the limit of severity of the tasks. After this day
freshmen will not be subjected to
further hazing.
A Board of Control should be instituted, composed mostly of freshmen, who may hear complaints
against the freshmen's deportment.
They should have the power of using their own discretion in dealing
with the offender, with a maximum
power of, say, reporting the offender to the Dean.
We recommend that the sophomore class be not the only class to
enforce these regulations, but that
the whole body of upper classmen
consider it a duty to enforce them.
It is all right that the sophomores
be in the majority at the Judgment
Day performance, but the other
classes should have a hand in the
affair also. Hazing and the enforcement of regulations by sophomores alone does the sophomores
more harm than it does good to the
freshmen. Its danger lies in the
fact that it is apt to give the man
of mean spirit an opportunity for

BALTIMORE

Getz Wins Banking Honor.

Charles Leland Getz, '13, of
Townsend Scott & Son, shared
with Lewis Kurtz, of D. Fahnestock & Co., a prize of forty dollars, offered by Waldo Newcomer,
president of the National Exchange
Bank, to the men who finished
highest in the examination held by
the Baltimore Chapter of the American Institute of Banking, on commercial and corporation law.
Thirty-one students took the examination, and Getz and Kurtz tied
for first honors. The original offer
was twenty-five dollars to the first
man and fifteen dollars to the second. The money was split.
Getz has just been elected to a
three-year term on the Board of
Governors of the Institute. He has
been with Townsend Scott & Son
since graduation 'from this University last June.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 25, 1914.

LEHIGH TRACK MEN MET DEFEAT

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

PRESIDENT GOODNOW'S FIRST MESSAGE TO HOPKINS STUDENTS

HARVARD DOWNED SECOND TIME

'Varsity Athletes Piled Up 63 Points to
Opponents' 41—One Record Broken.
Connolly Elected Captain.

Return Game at Cambridge Won By
One Point Margin--Pillow Fights and
Meeting of "Old Friends" Features.

The 'Varsity track and field team
lived up to expectations Saturday
at Homewood, downing Lehigh's
representatives 63 points to 41.
There was a stiff breeze during
the meet which prevented fast
times, and only one record fell, although two members of the Hopkins squad had hoped to establish
new marks. Randall, of Lehigh,
clipped an inch off the pole-vault
record when he went over the bar
at ii feet 8 inches.
There were several fast and hotly
contested events, and the meet was
a fitting close to Hopkins' spring
season.
The 200-yard dash was interesting because of a thrilling finish.
Lloyd had second position until the
last 20 yards, but nosed ahead on
a beautiful spurt, making the distance in 22 seconds. Lloyd was
also first in the 44o-yard run.
"Ben" Tappan, of Hopkins, won
both hurdle events; Swan, of Hopkins, being second in the 120-yard
event, and Turner Binford second
in the 220.
Harry Wagner won the woyard dash, but the time, toYs seconds, was higher than his usual
mark.
"Freddie" Lee, running his last
race for Hopkins, was first in the
two-mile. He won the event by
half a lap over Burns, of Lehigh.
After the meet, Gerald Connolly
was unanimously .selected to captain
next year's track and field team.
He is the veteran high juniper of
the squad, and will succeed Harry
Wagner, who will leave the University this year.
The summary:

For the second time this year the
lacrosse team triumphed over Harvard, the score being 5 to 4. The
team, accompanied by Messrs. W.
Schmeisser, Wolfe and H. Burgan,
left for Boston on Friday evening,
and in spite of several pillow-fights
and pajama parades, arrived safely
at their destination on Saturday
morning. After partaking of an
excellent feed at the Harvard 'Varsity' Club, the team departed for
the stadium to witness part of the
Harvard-Princeton baseball game
and the New England Intercollegiate Track Meet.
The game was called shortly after
four o'clock, and after the ball had
see-sawed up and down the field,
Hopkins scored the first tally. This
was followed a few minutes later
by one of ex-Capt. Houck's hard
shots, which resulted in a second
goal. Before the end of the half,
Abbe, though closely cornered,
managed to slip one past Goalkeeper Sears.
•
During the intermission, the team
was encopraged by the presence of
"Gil" Horax, "Jimmy" Easter, Ellis Ellicott, T. B. Price and Groundkeeper Chalk.
Hopkins, as usual, started the
second period with a rush, and in
a short time Voshell netted a pretty
goal from scrimmage. Harvard
showed good fighting qualities and
before the Hopkins defence could
recover, Nightingale and Fleming
both scored. To even up matters,
first Troxell then Voshell scored
for Hopkins. With seven minutes
to play, Elliott rolled an easy one
past Sears, who did not see it, making the score 5 to 4, in Hopkins'
favor.
In spite of strenuous efforts,
there was no more scoring by either
side. One of the features of the
game was the splendid work of
Captain Sutton, who repeatedly
captured the ball from the Harvard
attack and carried it past the midfield.

RHODES SCHOLARS DO WELL

GOOD CHEMISTS IN DEMAND

UNIVERSITY CALENDAR

Americans at Oxford Succeed in Nearly
All Activities According to Annual
Report—Not So Good in Classics.

Professor Baxter Tells of Wide Opportunities in the Industrial Field —"Efficiency Chemists" Needed.

The annual report of the Rhodes
scholarship trust, which has just
been issued, contains a statement
giving the young American Rhodes
scholars at Oxford credit for filling
well an important place in the life
and work of the ancient University. There are 175 scholarship
holders, about one-fourteenth of the
whole student body, a number that
offers abundant opportunity for influence on both sides.
The report grants that it is difficult to appraise relative merit, but
concedes that the Rhodes men are
standing the test of Oxford competition well in all studies, except the
classics. Last year they took five
out of the seven first honors in
jurisprudence. They won nine university prizes, some of them of
great importance — the Gladstone
memorial prize, the Mathew Arnold
prize for an English essay; the Oldham prize for a classical essay, and
the Beit prize in colonial history.
The 1913 prizes and honors won
by Rhodes men last year were more
numerous than in any earlier year.
An American also won last year,
for the first time, the presidency of
the Union, the highest undergraduate office. • In athletics they are
conspicuous. In the Oxford competition with Cambridge last year
five Americans were on the track
team.
Finally, the report sets at rest a
fear that some felt when the scholarships were established. Of the
431 Rhodes scholars who have finished their studies, only eleven have
gone to work in England, and most
of these only as a temporary arrangement. The remainder have
returned home, 144 to pursue education professionally, 113 law, 47
government service, 25 medicine, 18
business, 18 ministry, and others
journalism, scientific work and
farming.

Prof. G. P. Baxter, writing in the
Harvard Crimson, believes there is
a wide field of oportunity open to
efficient chemists in a great many
industries which heretofore have
not been concerned with the science.
He said:

FORMULATE NEW HAZING RULES
Freshman Committee Has Submitted to
the Faculty and Student Council
a Code of Regulations.

.\ ,vstem of hazing, based upon
a Code of Regulations which future
Hopkins freshmen will be expected
"to submit to and to obey," has
been presented to the Student
Council and the faculty by the
committee of freshmen on hazing
and freshman regulations, William
J. Fulton, chairman.
No action has been taken on the
new rules by either the Student
Council or the faculty, but if they
are accepted in whole or in part,
the first-year men will be expected
to follow them faithfully.
The greater part of the Code of
Regulations has been copied from
the system followed at Princeton,
while the rules for hazing represent, for the most part, the ideas
of the committee.
The verbatim report of the freshman committee is:
Since promiscuous hazing has
been abolished at this University,
yet believing that if it is done
systematically and in the right
spirit it will be of value to the
University and to the freshmen, we
submit to the Student Council and
the faculty of the Johns Hopkins
University a system of hazing and
a Code of Regulations which the
freshmen of this University are
expected to submit to and to obey.
Regulations.
1. Freshmen should not be boisterous, talk loudly, or- make unnecessary noises in or about the
buildings.
2. At no time during the year
should freshmen ride in the elevators.
3. Freshmen should show respect
to upper classmen by giving way
to them in all reasonable ways.
4. On or before the day of the
St. John's football game, freshmen
should not wear derby. hats or tan
shoes.
5. Until Commemoration Day,
freshmen should not wear loud
socks, vests, or ties, or shirts with
soft collars.
6. Freshmen should not wear
University colors in any form (permissible when representing the University in athletics).
7. Freshmen should not smoke
pipes or cigars on University property.
8. Freshmen should always carry
matches as a favor to upper classmen.
9. Unless accompanied by visitors or relatives no freshman should
occupy a seat in the stands at
Homewood Field, other than in the
rooters' section.
Freshmen should be present
at all athletic contests at Homewood Field.
1. Freshmen should be present
at every student meeting, at which
their presence is deemed important
by the organization holding it.

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 25, 1914.
12. The wearing of silk hats to
University functions is the privilege of juniors and seniors only.
13. Freshmen should wear the
"freshman button- always in the
lapel of the coat, in plain view.
While the University remains in
the city, the term "University property," in the seventh regulation, applies to that district bounded on the
north by Madison street, on the
south by Franklin street, on the
east by Howard street, and on the
west by Eutaw street. It also applies to all Homewood property.
As we think it unreasonable to
expect the freshmen to wear a
special skull cap in the city, we substitute, in the thirteenth regulation,
some form of button by which the
upper classmen can tell who are
freshmen. The form of this button
may be decided on by a committee.
The caps can be substituted for the
buttons when the University moves
to Homewood.

Hazing.
No secret or disorganized hazing
should be permitted to be indulged
in.
Let the third school day after the
second term begins be called Judgment Day. On this day at twothirty all freshmen are expected to
be present in the Cage. They should
be ready to do everything they
are ordered to do without complaint. A "Judgment" committee
of half the sophomore, one-third of
the junior and twenty of the senior
class be appointed by the class
presidents. This committee shall
meet a sufficient number of times
to assign tasks for each individual
freshman and to make complete arrangements for the affair. This
committee shall consider it their
duty to assign tasks to the individual
according to his conduct, freshness,.
or meekness. In this way the fresh
freshman will get his just deserts,
and the meek one who frequently
gets more than his share will be
justly treated. The Student Council should decide the limit of severity of the tasks. After this day
freshmen will not be subjected to
further hazing.
A Board of Control should be instituted, composed mostly of freshmen, who may hear complaints
against the freshmen's deportment.
They should have the power of using their own discretion in dealing
with the offender, with a maximum
power of, say, reporting the offender to the Dean.
We recommend that the sophomore class be not the only class to
enforce these regulations, but that
the whole body of upper classmen
consider it a duty to enforce them.
It is all right that the sophomores
be in the majority at the Judgment
Day performance, but the other
classes should have a hand in the
affair also. Hazing and the enforcement of regulations by sophomores alone does the sophomores
more harm than it does good to the
freshmen. Its danger lies in the
fact that it is apt to give the man
of mean spirit an opportunity for

We place the hazing day three

so that the characteristics of the

It is unfair to have this day so soon

BALTIMORE

Getz Wins Banking Honor.

Charles Leland Getz, '13, of
Townsend Scott & Son, shared
with Lewis Kurtz, of D. Fahnestock & Co., a prize of forty dollars, offered by Waldo Newcomer,
president of the National Exchange
Bank, to the men who finished
highest in the examination held by
the Baltimore Chapter of the American Institute of Banking, on commercial and corporation law.
Thirty-one students took the examination, and Getz and Kurtz tied
for first honors. The original offer
was twenty-five dollars to the first
man and fifteen dollars to the second. The money was split.
Getz has just been elected to a
three-year term on the Board of
Governors of the Institute. He has
been with Townsend Scott & Son
since graduation 'from this University last June.
